div.head: A DISCOURSE OF THE Countrey, Manners, Government, Original and Religion, OF THE COSSACKS.
div.p: THe name of CoÅ¿Å¿acks was given them by reaÅ¿on of their AddreÅ¿s and Agility in penetrating even in the moÅ¿t difficult and dangerous places Å¿uch as the mouth of the BoriÅ¿thenes, whereby they made War with the Turks and Tartars. CoÅ¿a Å¿ignifying in PoliÅ¿h, a Goat.

Long agoe from the time of SigiÅ¿mund the I. there were Voluntiers from the frontiers of RuÅ¿Å¿ia, Wolhinia, Podolia, and other Provinces of Poland, which met together to practiÅ¿e their Pyracies upon the Black Sea where they ordinarily met with conÅ¿iderable advantages, and brought away rich booty both from the TurkiÅ¿h Galleys and from the places where they often landed in Natolia, where they pillaged and Å¿acked whole Towns, as that of TrebiÅ¿onde and Synopa, having the boldneÅ¿s Å¿ometimes to come within two Leagues of ConÅ¿tantinople, and carry away priÅ¿oners and plunder: at the latter end of the year theÅ¿e adventurers retired home, appointing firÅ¿t their Rendezvous where they were to meet in the Spring in Å¿ome of the IÅ¿lands or Rocks of the BoriÅ¿thenes, from thence again to make their excurÅ¿ions.

King Stephen Batory, to whom Poland is beholden for many good Rules, conÅ¿idering the Å¿ervice which he might draw from theÅ¿e Rovers, towards the defence of the frontiers of RuÅ¿Å¿ia and
Podolia, which lay always expoÅ¿ed to the incurÅ¿ions of the Tartars, formed a Militia out of them, and gave them the Town of Trethymirow upon the BoriÅ¿thenes for a GarriÅ¿on, made a General over them, and gave him power to make under-Officers, granting them beÅ¿ides their pay, divers priviledges and immunities, and joyned to this Infantry of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks two thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e, for the Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿tance of which he deÅ¿igned the fourth part of his Crown-Lands whence they were called Quartani, and by corruption Quartiani.

TheÅ¿e forces thus eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed for the guard of the frontiers, did Å¿o Å¿ecure it againÅ¿t the irruptions of the Tartars that all the deÅ¿art Countrey, beyond the Towns of Bracklaw, Bar, and Kiovia, began to be peopled, and many Towns and FortreÅ¿Å¿es were built there, every one bringing in Colonies from the neighboring Provinces.

This Militia thus regulated; Å¿uÅ¿tained it Å¿elf and rendred good Å¿ervice to the
Crown of Poland, without compariÅ¿on, more profitably then before, when being diÅ¿perÅ¿ed and Å¿cattered about, they could not act together in company. Yet as this union was Å¿o advantagious for the making head againÅ¿t the Tartars, and for defending of the Frontiers, Å¿o in Å¿hort time it became prejudicial and deÅ¿tructive to the Poles, againÅ¿t whom they many times rebelled; for the CoÅ¿Å¿acks finding themÅ¿elves to be of Å¿uch importance, would Å¿carce receive any Orders from their Superiors, nor acknowledge their MaÅ¿ters upon whom they depended. Their firÅ¿t Rebellion was in 1587. under John Podkowa, their General, who was overthrown, and in the end loÅ¿t his head.

In the year 1596. King SigiÅ¿mund the III. having prohibited their Pyracies on the Black Sea, upon the complaints which he received from the Grand Signior; they did indeed give them over, but it was, that they might fall upon RuÅ¿Å¿ia and Lythuania with the greater force, where they committed unheard of violences
under the Conduct of Naleuaiko their General. In vain were Orders Å¿ent for their diÅ¿arming and returning home, they deÅ¿piÅ¿ed all, and united themÅ¿elves more Å¿trictly under their head, to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the PoliÅ¿h Army, which General Zolkiewski was forced to bring againÅ¿t them, him therefore they expected with a firm reÅ¿olution near the City of Bialicerkiew and fought the Polanders, and at firÅ¿t got the better, but Zolkiewski, who was a great Warrier, having at length Å¿hut them in, and forced them into diÅ¿advantagious Å¿tations, obliged them to deliver up Nalevaiko, who had the Å¿ame end with his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or.

In 1637. the CoÅ¿Å¿acks revolted again, but with as bad Å¿ucceÅ¿s as before, the cauÅ¿e of their Revolt was, That divers of the PoliÅ¿h Nobility having obtained by gift Å¿ome Lands upon thoÅ¿e frontiers, and in thoÅ¿e places deÅ¿igned for the quartering of this Militia, the more to augment their Revenues they were deÅ¿irous to bring their new Subjects to the Å¿ame days works as thoÅ¿e of the other
Provinces of Poland are bound to; and therefore they perÅ¿waded King Æ²ladeÅ¿laus and the States, that it was neceÅ¿Å¿ary to chaÅ¿tiÅ¿e the inÅ¿olency of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks, they being able moÅ¿t of all to croÅ¿s this deÅ¿igne, as being a free people, and cauÅ¿ing by their example the other Countrey-men to bear their yoak more impatiently. So that it was reÅ¿olved that a Fort Å¿hould be built in a place called Kudak, upon the BoriÅ¿thenes, a Å¿cituation very proper for the brideling of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks, it being near the Porohi or Rocks of the River which they made uÅ¿e of for their moÅ¿t Å¿ecure Retreat, and becauÅ¿e they did immediately miÅ¿truÅ¿t Colonel Marion a Frenchman, whom the General KonieÅ¿polski had left with two hundred men to build this Fort, he cauÅ¿ed part of his Troops to winter there till it might be fit for defence. The CoÅ¿Å¿acks underÅ¿tanding well upon what deÅ¿igne this Fort was built, took the Alarme at the firÅ¿t, and gathered themÅ¿elves together in the greateÅ¿t number that they could, but entring at that very time when they had moÅ¿t need of union, into diÅ¿cord and diÅ¿truÅ¿t

The loÅ¿s of their Generals was Å¿econded by the loÅ¿s of their priviledges and the Town of Trethymirow granted to them formerly by King Stephen, and at ength alÅ¿o by the Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ion of their Militia, which the King of Poland Commanded

They were therefore Å¿ome time after Å¿et up again, and King Æ²ladiÅ¿laus, who made great account of this Militia in the war, which he intended to make againÅ¿t the Turks and Tartars, was no Å¿mall contributor to their total reeÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment, making Bogdan Kmielniski, one of their own body, General over them, and withal increaÅ¿ing their number.

From all this diÅ¿courÅ¿e we may at preÅ¿ent infer, that the CoÅ¿Å¿acks are rather a Militia then a Nation, as moÅ¿t have thought, and we cannot better compare
them then to the free Archers formerly eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed in France by Charles the VII. who were perÅ¿ons fit for Arms choÅ¿en out of all the Towns of his Dominion, and who upon the firÅ¿t Orders from the King, were bound to meet at a general Rendezvous, and to Å¿erve in the wars; by which they were exempted from all Taxes and ImpoÅ¿ts. The CoÅ¿Å¿acks are the Å¿ame, choÅ¿en and liÅ¿ted in RuÅ¿Å¿ia, Volhinia and Podolia, and who enjoying many exemptions and priviledges, are in like manner bound to march whereÅ¿oever they are commanded; formerly they had no more then one onely Town for their retreat, as hath been already obÅ¿erved, and the Porohi of the BoriÅ¿thenes, from whence they were called Zaporouski CoÅ¿Å¿acks, and are hereby diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed from the CoÅ¿Å¿acks in MoÅ¿covia and from thoÅ¿e upon the River Don or Tanais.

Porohi, is a RuÅ¿Å¿ian term, Å¿ignifying a rocky Stone; this River at fifty Leagues from the mouth of it, is croÅ¿Å¿ed with a ridge of Rocks, which maketh a kind of
damme or cataract, and by this means rendreth the Navigation in thoÅ¿e parts impoÅ¿Å¿ible, and taketh away from Æ²krain the means of inriching it Å¿elf by the Traffick which it might otherwiÅ¿e have with ConÅ¿tantinople for Corn and other MerchandiÅ¿es in which it aboundeth as much as any other Countrey in the world; Å¿ome of theÅ¿e Rocks are even with the water, others are above the water, the height of Å¿ix, eight, and ten feet, and from this inequality there are in the River divers caÅ¿cades or falls which the CoÅ¿Å¿acks themÅ¿elves doe not paÅ¿s but with a great deal of danger; there are thirteen of theÅ¿e falls, Å¿ome of which are fourteen or fifteen foot high, when the water is low, and it is as neceÅ¿Å¿ary for a true Zaporouski CoÅ¿Å¿ack to have paÅ¿Å¿ed theÅ¿e falls, and to have made a voyage upon the Black Sea, as for a Knight of Maltha before he come to the dignity of that Order, to have been in a Summers Expedition againÅ¿t the Turks.

Below the Porohi there are divers IÅ¿lands in the River BoriÅ¿thenes, and amongÅ¿t
others there is one very remarkable, Å¿omewhat lower then the entrance of the River Czertomelik, compaÅ¿Å¿ed about with thouÅ¿ands of other little IÅ¿les, Å¿ome of which are dry, others marÅ¿hy, and all of them covered with Reeds, in Å¿uch manner as it is hard to perceive the Channels which Å¿eparate them; into this place, and into theÅ¿e windings and turnings the CoÅ¿Å¿acks make their retreat, which they call their SkarbniÅ¿a, Woyskowa, that is to Å¿ay, the TreaÅ¿ure of their Army, and here they Å¿hut up their booty which they have taken in their Pyracies upon the Black Sea, the accceÅ¿s to this place is Å¿o difficult and dangerous, that many TurkiÅ¿h Galleys in purÅ¿uing them thither, have been loÅ¿t, and it is here that the CoÅ¿Å¿acks hold their Rendezvous before they put out to Å¿ea.

After their arrival they chooÅ¿e a General to Conduct and Command them in their Expedition, and then fall to work about their Boats, which are about threeÅ¿core foot long, and eleven or twelve foot broad, they have no Keel, but are
built onely upon a bottom of Willow or Limetree, Å¿ided or raiÅ¿ed with plancks, which they pin one into another; the better to Å¿teer them when they are forced to flye, they have two Oars or Skulls on purpoÅ¿e, their Å¿ides are Å¿trengthened with Roaps of Reeds, as thick as a Barrel, to Å¿uÅ¿tain theÅ¿e Boats againÅ¿t the fury of the waves, they have ordinarily ten or twelve Oars on each Å¿ide, and rowe Å¿wifter then the TurkiÅ¿h Galleys; they have but a bad Å¿ail, and make uÅ¿e of it onely in fair weather, and chooÅ¿e rather to rowe when the wind is high; for their proviÅ¿ions in their voyage they take with them BiÅ¿cuit, put up in a Tunn, and as they have uÅ¿e for it, take it out at the bung: beÅ¿ides this, they have a Barrel of boiled Millet, and another of PaÅ¿te mingled with water which they eat with the Millet, and it Å¿erves them both for meat and drink, and is counted by them a delitious diÅ¿h; they carry no Aqua-vitae nor other Strong-waters, for although they be as Å¿ubject to drunkenneÅ¿s as any other Northern Nation, yet they are wonderfully Å¿ober in War.

When they meet with any Galley or VeÅ¿Å¿el (which they diÅ¿cover better, and at a greater diÅ¿tance then they can be diÅ¿covered) their Boats being but two foot and an half above water) they approach towards them till night, keeping at about a Leagues diÅ¿tance, and then well obÅ¿erving the place where they Å¿aw the veÅ¿Å¿el, they begin to rowe about midnight with all their force, and encompaÅ¿Å¿ing it about, take it at unawares, it being impoÅ¿Å¿ible for a VeÅ¿Å¿el beÅ¿et with Å¿uch a number of Boats all at once, to diÅ¿ingage or defend itÅ¿elf; they take out the Money, Guns, and all the MerchandiÅ¿e which they can conveniently carry away, and afterwards Å¿ink the Å¿hip, they being not dextrous enough to carry her off, but as they have this advantage by night over Å¿hips and Galleys,
Å¿o they are at great diÅ¿advantage by day, for theÅ¿e with their great Cannon Å¿hot Å¿catter them, and kill many of their men, and then eÅ¿pecially when they doe moÅ¿t vigorouÅ¿ly proÅ¿ecute their fight; from whence they oft bring back but halfe their equipage, though true it is, that they are Å¿eldom taken, by reaÅ¿on when they are purÅ¿ued, they can retire into the Reeds or near the Å¿hoares, where the Galleys cannot come. The Grand Signior hath often complained of their Pyracies to the King of Poland, who never yet gave him any greater Å¿atisfaction for his Dammages, then he hath received from him, for the inroads of the Tartars, to whom there could never be raiÅ¿ed up a more Å¿utable Enemy then theÅ¿e CoÅ¿Å¿acks.

As to their manner of making war by Land, they are better Foot-men then HorÅ¿e, they are patient, and laborious, obedient to their Commanders, and extremely dextrous at caÅ¿ting up earth, and intrenching; and not onely Å¿o, but alÅ¿o at another kind of ambulatory way

Chariots, which is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary when they march through thoÅ¿e great deÅ¿art Plains, where the Tartars run about continually: a thouÅ¿and CoÅ¿Å¿acks thus defended with their Chariots, will make head againÅ¿t Å¿ix thouÅ¿and of thoÅ¿e Infidels, who Å¿eldom alight from their HorÅ¿es, Å¿o that a Ditch or a Å¿mall baricado is able to Å¿top them, it would be very difficult in any other Countrey to make an Army march thus in the middle of Chariots, there being few Countreys in the world Å¿o flat and even as that.

The principal Rivers are the Nieper or BoriÅ¿thenes, the Bog, the NieÅ¿ter or Tyras, which bounds Walachia, the Dezna, the Ros, the Horin, the Slucz, the Ster, and many other leÅ¿Å¿er Rivers and Streams, by the number of which we may judge of the goodneÅ¿s of the Soil.

The moÅ¿t conÅ¿iderable Towns and FortreÅ¿Å¿es poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by the CoÅ¿Å¿acks are Kiovia, where there is a Palatinate and
a Metropolitan Greek Church, Bialacerkiew, KorÅ¿un, ConÅ¿tantinow, Bar, CzarkaÅ¿Å¿i, Czehrin, Kudak, Jampol, at a paÅ¿Å¿age over the NieÅ¿ter, Braclaw upon the Bog, a Palatinacy, Winnicza, Human, Czernihow, PereaÅ¿law, Lubnie, Pawoloiz, ChwaÅ¿tow, all theÅ¿e places have been fortified within theÅ¿e few years; and the Sieur de Beauplan, a French Ingenier in the Å¿ervice of the Great General KonieÅ¿polki, and to whom the publick is obliged for two exact Maps which he hath made of the Æ²krain, hath delineated and traced the Fortifications of the moÅ¿t part of theÅ¿e places, beÅ¿ides which, there is not a Town or Habitation which hath not a Rampant, or is not at leaÅ¿t defended with a Ditch to Å¿ecure it Å¿elf againÅ¿t the aÅ¿Å¿aults of the Tartars, who come often to viÅ¿it theÅ¿e Countreys.

The PeaÅ¿ants in Æ²krain, and the neighbouring Provinces are like Slaves, the Å¿ame as they are in almoÅ¿t all places of Poland, being forced to work three or four days in the week for their Landlords,
and are charged beÅ¿ides with many other duties, as of Corn and Fowl, for the Lands which they hold, and to pay the Tenth of Sheep and Hogs, and all Fruit, and to carry Wood and doe divers other days works; add to this the ill treatment which they receive from the Jews, who are Farmers of the Noblemens Lands, and who before the wars did exact all theÅ¿e Duties with a great deal of rigor; and beÅ¿ides that had Farmed out the Brewing of Beer, and the making of Strong-waters, Å¿o that we need not wonder Å¿o much at their frequent revolting, and that in theÅ¿e laÅ¿t wars they diÅ¿puted and defended their liberty with Å¿o much obÅ¿tinacy; for this Å¿evere Å¿ervitude hath diÅ¿cloÅ¿ed all theÅ¿e brave Zaporowski CoÅ¿Å¿acks, whoÅ¿e number is much increaÅ¿ed of late years, through the diÅ¿pair into which, the Å¿everity of the Gentlemen and the Jews, caÅ¿t the people of this Frontier, which hath conÅ¿trained them to Å¿eek their Liberties, or the end of their MiÅ¿eries among the reÅ¿t.

The inhabitants of Æ²krain, who are all at preÅ¿ent called CoÅ¿Å¿acks, and glory in carrying that name, are of a good Å¿tature, active, Å¿trong, and dextrous in what they doe, liberal, and little caring to gather Riches, great lovers of Liberty, and that cannot Å¿uffer any yoak; unwearied, bold and brave, but very great drunkards; perfidious and treacherous; they delight in Hunting and FiÅ¿hing, and in all Arts neceÅ¿Å¿ary to a Countrey-life, and to war, they have alÅ¿o this peculiar Art, that they underÅ¿tand beÅ¿t how to prepare Salt-peter with which their Countrey aboundeth, and from whence great quantity is tranÅ¿ported into divers places of Europe; they carry much of it to Dantzick where the Hollanders and other Nations receive it.

This Countrey is very much incommodated with Flies, which Å¿ting Å¿o fiercely in Summer, as to make their faces all Å¿welled, who doe not lie under a kind of Net made like a Å¿oldiers Hut, covered with a cotton Cloth tucked in
on the Å¿ides, and hanging down half a foot below the Bed, Å¿o that there may be left no place open: but they are much more infeÅ¿ted with LocuÅ¿ts which come in Å¿ome years, eÅ¿pecially in very dry Å¿eaÅ¿ons; they are brought by an EaÅ¿t or SoutheaÅ¿t wind out of Tartary, CarcaÅ¿Å¿ia, and Mengrelia, which Countreys are Å¿carce ever free from them; they come in clouds of five or Å¿ix Leagues long, and three or four Leagues broad, and darken the Air in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that the moÅ¿t clear weather becomes dusky; whereÅ¿oever they Å¿tay, they reap all the Corn in leÅ¿s then two hours time, though it be but green: theÅ¿e InÅ¿ects live but Å¿ix months; in the places where they Å¿tay; in Autumn they lay their Eggs, every one about three hundred, and in the following Å¿pring they are hatched, and if the weather be drie, turn into Å¿o many LocuÅ¿ts, the great Rains kill them, and by this means this Countrey is delivered from that Å¿courge, or elÅ¿e by the North and NorthweÅ¿t winds, which drive them into the Black Å¿ea, when they are newly hatched,
and are not yet turned into Flies, they creep into HouÅ¿es, into Beds, upon the Tables, and upon the Meat, Å¿o that they cannot eat without Å¿wallowing Å¿ome of them: in the night they fall down into the high-ways and fields, which are Å¿ometimes covered with them, and when a Chariot comes to paÅ¿s over them, they Å¿end forth an intolerable ill Å¿mell.

The RuÅ¿Å¿ians and CoÅ¿Å¿acks are afflicted with a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e called by the PhyÅ¿itians, Plica, and in the language of the Countrey GoÅ¿cheÅ¿t, they who are Å¿eized with it, looÅ¿e the uÅ¿e of their Limbs, as Paralitical perÅ¿ons doe, feeling great pains in their Nerves; this is followed by a great Å¿weat in their Head, and after that, their Hair is all glued together, at which time the palÅ¿ie leaveth them, but their Hair remaineth wreathed and in Elves-locks; this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e which is incident to HorÅ¿es as well as Men, is thought incurable in that Countrey, but the Sieur de Beauplan aÅ¿Å¿ures us he hath cured many, by treating them in the
Å¿ame manner as thoÅ¿e who are infected with the Lues Venerea, and Å¿ome have been inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly delivered from it by the change of Air in paÅ¿Å¿ing from one Countrey to another; this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e proceedeth according to the common opinion from the crudity or Å¿ome other bad quality of their waters; and this is remarkable in it, that it is communicated by Coition, as the French Pox: Some Children bring it with them into the world, and are cured as they grow up.
The language of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks is a dialect of the Polonian, as that is of the Slavonian; it is very delicate, and aboundeth in Diminitives and pretty FaÅ¿hions, and Manners, of elegant Speech.

As to their Religion, they make profeÅ¿Å¿ion of the Greek, received in this Countrey in the year 942. in the Reign of Wlodomir Prince of RuÅ¿Å¿ia, the greater part of the Gentlemen profeÅ¿s either the Catholick, Lutheran, or CalviniÅ¿t.

The Principal points in the Greek Religion wherein they differ from the Latine are, That they doe not admit of the proceeding of the Holy GhoÅ¿t from the Father and the Son, but from the Father onely, thinking that if they Å¿hould believe him to proceed from both, it would Å¿uppoÅ¿e in him a double UnderÅ¿tanding, and a double Will.

The Greeks alÅ¿o deny Purgatory, Å¿aying, That every one after this life according to his actions in it, is to expect the day of judgement; the good in pleaÅ¿ant and delicious places with the good Å¿pirits, and the evil in frightful and terrible habitations in company of the bad: founding this their belief upon that paÅ¿Å¿age of Scripture, Venite benedicti patris mei poÅ¿Å¿idere regnum coelorum, &c. & ite maledicti in ignem aeternum; from whence they pretend to prove that there is no other judgement but that of the end of the world, it Å¿eeming to them incongruous that this Å¿entence Å¿hould be pronounced againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e who are already judged.

They doe not admit of the Å¿ingle lives of PrieÅ¿ts, and receive none to that function but Å¿uch as are married, beleeving that the Roman PrieÅ¿ts are anathematized by the Councel held at Gangra in the fourth Canon of which it is Å¿aid, Qui Å¿pernit Å¿acerdotem Å¿ecundum legem uxorem habentem, dicens quod non liceat de manibus ejus Sacramentum Å¿umere anathema Å¿it: and in another place, omnis Å¿acerdos & diaconus propriam uxorem dimittens, Å¿acerdotio privetur, Å¿o that they hold Marriage to be Å¿o EÅ¿Å¿ential to the prieÅ¿thood that a PrieÅ¿t when he burieth his Wife can no longer exerciÅ¿e his Å¿acerdotal Functions; theÅ¿e PrieÅ¿ts are ordinarily taken out of Colledges or MonaÅ¿teries, where they chooÅ¿e thoÅ¿e of longeÅ¿t Å¿tanding and greateÅ¿t abilities.

They refuÅ¿e all Councels, Å¿ince the Å¿eventh Oecumenical AÅ¿Å¿embled under Pope Adrian, in which they Å¿ay it was determined, that all things decided and reÅ¿olved of in the preceding Council, till that time, Å¿hould remain firm and
Å¿table for ever, but that whoÅ¿oever for the future Å¿hould aÅ¿Å¿emble any other Council, or meet at it, Å¿hould be an Anathema, Å¿o that they count all what hath been determined of in the Church Å¿ince that time to be Heretical and corrupted. The Fathers which they follow, are S. Bazile, S. Gregory Nazianzen, S. ChryÅ¿oÅ¿tome; they read alÅ¿o the Morals of S. Gregory the Great, and having a great opinion of their Sanctity, they hold in great Veneration all the Popes who were before the Seventh Council. They celebrate their Liturgy in Greece, and in Natolia in the antient Greek Language, but the MuÅ¿covites and RuÅ¿Å¿ians have it in their own, yet they alÅ¿o mix Å¿ome Greek Hymnes with it, they conÅ¿ecrate with leavened Bread, and think it Å¿trange that the Roman PrieÅ¿ts Å¿hould make uÅ¿e of unleavened, and Å¿hould imitate the Jews in this, and yet not retain their Sabboth or CircumciÅ¿ion: beÅ¿ides, they Å¿ay it is expreÅ¿ly Å¿et down in the GoÅ¿pel, That our Saviour at the laÅ¿t Supper took Bread, which cannot be taken for unleavened Bread,
for the Jews eat not of that but at the PaÅ¿sover, and Å¿tanding, when on the contrary, Our Lord at the inÅ¿titution of the laÅ¿t Supper, Å¿ate down, or rather laid down with the ApoÅ¿tles, recumbentibus duodecem, &c. and whence they conclude that he did not then keep the PaÅ¿sover, but that it was Å¿ome other repaÅ¿t. They invoke Saints and Angels as thoÅ¿e of the Roman Church doe, and the bleÅ¿Å¿ed Virgin and the ApoÅ¿tles, whoÅ¿e FeÅ¿tivals they Å¿olemnize; and the RuÅ¿Å¿ians, principally that of S. Nicholas of Myrea, whom they particularly adore.

Their BaptiÅ¿me, ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, Marriage, Ordination of their PrieÅ¿ts, and their extreme Unction, differ little from the Latines, the difference which there is in the EuchariÅ¿t is, that the people communicate in both kinds, and that the Sacrament is adminiÅ¿tred to Children of three years old, they have their HoÅ¿tia's apart for the Å¿ick, which they conÅ¿ecrate in the Holy week.

Their FaÅ¿ts are more frequent and more auÅ¿tere then ours, they abÅ¿tain not onely from FleÅ¿h, but from Butter, Milk, CheeÅ¿e, Eggs, and FiÅ¿h alÅ¿o, living onely upon Cabbage, parÅ¿nips, MuÅ¿hrooms, and PulÅ¿e; there are Å¿ome alÅ¿o Å¿o devout that they content themÅ¿elves with Bread and Water, excepting Saturdays and Sundays, yet for all this the MuÅ¿covites are often drunk in their Lents, and doe not believe any more then the Polanders, that exceÅ¿Å¿ive drinking doth any way break their FaÅ¿ts; they have four FaÅ¿ts in the year, the firÅ¿t anÅ¿wereth to our Lent, and laÅ¿ts Å¿even weeks; the Å¿econd beginneth from the Octave after WhitÅ¿untide, and ends at the Vigils of S. Peter and S. Paul; the third from the firÅ¿t of AuguÅ¿t to the AÅ¿Å¿umption of the bleÅ¿Å¿ed Virgin; and the laÅ¿t is during the Advent, which beginneth fifteen days Å¿ooner then that of the Church of Rome, they obÅ¿erve the Å¿ame abÅ¿tinence on WedneÅ¿days and Fridays; there are very few points in which the RuÅ¿Å¿ian and Greek Church differ, they holding the Å¿ame Communion and
fourÅ¿core years Å¿ince did acknowledge the Patriarch of ConÅ¿tantinople, Å¿ince which time the Great Duke of MuÅ¿covy hath thought fit to nominate the ArchbiÅ¿hop of MoÅ¿co, upon which nomination he is conÅ¿ecrated by two or three of his Suffragans. The BiÅ¿hops of Black RuÅ¿Å¿ia or Southern RuÅ¿Å¿ia did Å¿ince that Å¿et up a Church apart, and Å¿eeing the progreÅ¿s of the diviÅ¿ions which Luther and Calvin had made in their reÅ¿pective Countreys, they determined in a Synod which they held for the Å¿uÅ¿taining of themÅ¿elves, to re-eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the union of their Church with the Roman Catholick, and to this intent, in the year 1595. they deputed two, and Å¿ent them to Rome, who in the name of the Churches of Black RuÅ¿Å¿ia, preÅ¿ented in writing a confeÅ¿Å¿ion of Faith conformable to the belief of the Council of Trent, after that they had Å¿tipulated that they Å¿hould retain the Ceremonies of the Greek Church uÅ¿ed when the union was made with the Latine at the Council of Florence, but they are Å¿ince fallen off.

div.head: A DISCOURSE OF THE PRAECOPIAN TARTARS.
div.p:
THere are two great Nations in the world, who live very much after the Å¿ame manner, are of the Å¿ame Religion, and pretend to the Å¿ame original; theÅ¿e are the Arabs and the Tartars, the firÅ¿t living in part of AÅ¿ia and of Africa, and the latter poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ing all the Northern Regions of AÅ¿ia, and extending their Territories into Europe: Å¿ome of theÅ¿e are more civilized then the others, have Towns and Literature, and improve their knowledge
in Arts and Sciences, but the moÅ¿t part of them live a wandring life up and down in the Fields and Plains, in Tents or Sheds, or elÅ¿e contended to have no other covering but the Heaven, not addicting themÅ¿elves to Agriculture, but delight in Hunting, Fighting, Robbing, and have little other Riches then their Heards and Flocks.

All theÅ¿e Tartars are divided into Hordes,
Horde Å¿ignifies a Congregation. and the Arabs into Heyles or Cobeyles, and almoÅ¿t all theÅ¿e people, make no allyance out of their own Lineage and Blood, from whence apparently proceeds, that great reÅ¿emblance which they have to one another; and Å¿ome peculiar Features which doe eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h them from other Nations.

The Tartars have not been known by this name, but for about four hundred years, and are properly the Scythians; Å¿ome Authors, as Leunclave and others, derive this name from the River Tartar, in the Countrey where they did inhabit.

There are Å¿ome who Å¿ay that the name of Tartar is improper and corrupted, and that they ought to be called Tatares or Totares, a word which in the Syriack Language Å¿ignifies a Remnant, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing that theÅ¿e people are the remnant of the Ten Tribes which Salmanazar and his predeceÅ¿Å¿ors led away captive into AÅ¿Å¿yria, and who afterwards reÅ¿olved to Å¿eparate themÅ¿elves from the Gentiles, and paÅ¿Å¿ed into a Countrey not inhabited, there to exerciÅ¿e their Religion, and to obÅ¿erve the laws which they had formerly neglected.

Tartary is devided into five parts, the firÅ¿t is the leÅ¿Å¿er Tartary, or Tartary of Prezecop, called alÅ¿o Crim Tartary. The Å¿econd is Sarmatia, AÅ¿iatica, which containeth many Hordes of the Tartars Å¿ubject to the Great Duke of MoÅ¿covia, as the CzeremiÅ¿Å¿es, the Nagais, Zauolhaus, and thoÅ¿e of Cazan and AÅ¿tracan. The Third is Zagatay, or the Countrey of Æ²zbek, otherwiÅ¿e called Scythia beyond the Mount Imaus, which extends it Å¿elf
between the Rivers of CheÅ¿el, otherwiÅ¿e Jaxarte, and Gehon, or Oxe, and comprehendeth Bactriana, and Sogdiana; and in this Tartary Reigned the famous Tamberlane. The Fourth is Cathay or great Tartary. And the Fifth is, That Tartary which was unknown to Ptolomy and lieth moÅ¿t remote in the North-eaÅ¿t part of AÅ¿ia.

The leÅ¿Å¿er Tartary formerly called Taurica CherÅ¿oneÅ¿us, hath received the name of PraecopenÅ¿is, from a Town called Przecop, Å¿cituated in the IÅ¿tmus of the PeninÅ¿ula. Przecop in the Sclavovian Language, Å¿ignifying a place ditched or digged; there being a Ditch which cutteth through this neck of Land; it is called alÅ¿o Crim, from one of its principal Towns of that name.

The Tauri were the antient inhabitants, and gave name to this Countrey, many Greek Colonies came thither afterwards, and then Å¿ome Hordes of the Tartars who came out from about the CaÅ¿pian Sea, and after they had harraÅ¿ed
a part of AÅ¿ia and paÅ¿Å¿ed the Volga, did at length fall into this Countrey, and take poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of it all, about 460. years Å¿ince, except Caffa and Å¿ome other Ports which remained in the hands of the GenoeÅ¿es from the year one thouÅ¿and two hundred and Å¿ixty Å¿ix, till one thouÅ¿and four hundred and Å¿eventy four, when Mahomet the Å¿econd Emperor of the Turks took it from them.

Taurica CherÅ¿oneÅ¿us is about fifty Leagues long, and in Å¿ome parts thirty Leagues broad, in others leÅ¿s; but the leÅ¿Å¿er Tartary is of a greater extent, comeprehending Budziak, which is a Countrey lying between the NieÅ¿ter and the BoriÅ¿thenes, as far as the Don or Tanais, and all along the Sea of Elle Zabacche, or Palus Maeotis.

There are no Towns nor yet Villages, but in the CherÅ¿oneÅ¿us, the reÅ¿t being only incultivated Plains, yet of themÅ¿elves very fruitful, and the Tartars encamp up and down in them as they find more or leÅ¿s forrage, and make uÅ¿e
of their Huts, and their travelling Å¿heds, onely in the winter to defend themÅ¿elves againÅ¿t the great cold and Å¿now, which we mean alÅ¿o of thoÅ¿e onely who are left to keep the Herds and Flocks; as for the reÅ¿t they are ordinarily employed about this time, when the Rivers and MarÅ¿hes are frozen up, to make their inroads, and plunder in Æ²krain, and upon the frontiers of MoÅ¿covy.

The Towns of this PeninÅ¿ula are firÅ¿t Przecop, called Or by the Tartars, where there are about four hundred HouÅ¿es; it is Å¿cituated upon the EaÅ¿tern part of the IÅ¿tmus, being half a League about: CoÅ¿low, Å¿eated on one of the Capes of the PeninÅ¿ula upon the Black Sea, having about two thouÅ¿and HouÅ¿es, and is a Town of Trade belonging to the Cham: Crim, another Town of the Cham's, Å¿cituated upon a Bay which the Palus Maeotis maketh, and is inhabited by few elÅ¿e but by the Tartars. BaciaÅ¿ary where the Cham ordinarily keepeth his Court of about two thouÅ¿and HouÅ¿es. AlmaÅ¿aray,
another Palace belonging to the Cham, whither he often goeth, but the Town by it hath not above three or fourÅ¿core HouÅ¿es.

The places poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by the Turk, are the Port of Baluelawa, very much eÅ¿teemed, where the Ships and Galleys are made for him, but there are not there above two hundred HouÅ¿es at moÅ¿t. Ingermen, and Mancup, CaÅ¿tles with ruined Towns, but the moÅ¿t conÅ¿iderable place is Caffa, formerly called TheodoÅ¿ia, when the GenoeÅ¿es were MaÅ¿ters of it, it was one of the moÅ¿t trading Towns of the Levant, but it is Å¿ince faln from its Grandeur, and hath run the Å¿ame fortune with moÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e Towns, which have fallen under the Ottoman Dominion; yet there are Å¿till remaining about five or Å¿ix thouÅ¿and HouÅ¿es: the Inhabitants are Greeks, Italians; the remainder of the GenoeÅ¿es, Armenians, Jews, Turks and Tartars, but the moÅ¿t part of them are ChriÅ¿tians, who have had to the number of five and forty Churches there, either Greek, Arminian, or Latine.

Taurica CherÅ¿oneÅ¿us conÅ¿iÅ¿teth partly of fruitful Plains, and partly of Woods and Hills, it produceth all Å¿ort of Grain and excellent Fruit and Wine. The ChriÅ¿tians and Jews Till the Ground; the Tartars imploy their Slaves in the Å¿ame labor, eÅ¿teeming it an employment below them, but the Tartars without, deÅ¿piÅ¿e it more, and chooÅ¿e rather to be Shepheards and Robbers: Their HorÅ¿es and Cattel are their Riches, with the Booty and Slaves of both Sexes, which they take in their incurÅ¿ions and Å¿ell to the Merchants of Caffa, after they have provided for themÅ¿elves, and furniÅ¿hed the Cham, who hath the priviledge to take firÅ¿t what Men and Women he pleaÅ¿eth; theÅ¿e Slaves are afterwards carried away by the Merchants of ConÅ¿tantinople, Synopa and TrebiÅ¿onde, and other places of the EaÅ¿t, eÅ¿pecially the Women and Maids of Poland, who are carried away Å¿ometimes as far as PerÅ¿ia and India, to furniÅ¿h the Serraglio's of thoÅ¿e Countreys where they are much eÅ¿teemed; formerly the Soldans of Aegypt did furniÅ¿h
themÅ¿elves with Soldiers out of Taurica CherÅ¿oneÅ¿us, compoÅ¿ing their Militia of Slaves taken by the Tartars in RuÅ¿Å¿ia, Podolia, MoÅ¿covia, and CircaÅ¿Å¿ia. But Å¿ince the ruine of that Military Empire by Selim, that Commerce with Aegypt hath ceaÅ¿ed. The Tartars receive from the ChriÅ¿tian and JewiÅ¿h Merchants in exchange for their Slaves and Cattel which they bring them, TurkiÅ¿h HorÅ¿es, Arms, Stuffs for cloathing and other Commodities.

The Praecopian Tartars are moÅ¿t of them of a middle Å¿tature, Å¿trong, and thick Limbs, Å¿hort Neck, broad Face, their Eyes Å¿mall, but very black, and opening wide, their complexion Tawny, and other particular Lineaments they have which doe eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h them from among many other men, hardened to all Å¿ort of Labour and Pains from their very infancy. Their Mothers hath them almoÅ¿t every day in water, in which Salt is diÅ¿Å¿olved, to make their bodies more Å¿trong, and leÅ¿s apt to be penetrated by the injuries of
the Air, which I have Å¿een alÅ¿o practiÅ¿ed by the PoliÅ¿h Women, but theÅ¿e are contented to prepare this Lye onely once a week, their Fathers teach them very early to draw the bowe, and from the age of twelve or fifteen years they carry them with them to the wars.

The Tartars who live abroad, are habited in Sheep-skins with a Cap of the Å¿ame Stuffe; their Arms are ordinarily a Cimeter, a Bow and a Quiver, with about twenty Arrows; they make themÅ¿elves theÅ¿e Arms, thus, their Bows out of HorÅ¿es Pizzels, their Quiver, out of his skin, and tye the heads of their Arrows with little Thongs cut out of the Å¿ame skin of the Å¿ame Animal, of which alÅ¿o they make their Whips Å¿o neatly, by a particular Art which they have, that our Sadlers in France and Germany, have not yet been able to imitate them; they begin to uÅ¿e Fire-arms, and all of them are furniÅ¿h'd with Knives and InÅ¿truments to mend their Bridles and Saddles, which they alÅ¿o make themÅ¿elves; they carry
with them a Steel to Å¿trike fire, and a Mariners CompaÅ¿s, a Sun-dyal to guide them through the deÅ¿art Plains where there is no beaten way or path. The chief among them wear Cloth of divers colours, have Linnen made of Cotton, Coats of Mail, TurkiÅ¿h Saddles, and are in an handÅ¿ome equipage, purchaÅ¿ed either of the Armenian Merchants, or taken in War; all ride very Å¿hort, and carry their Legs bended and high, after the manner of the Poles, Turks, Arabs, and of all the EaÅ¿tern Nations, and the Africans. Their HorÅ¿es which they call Bacmates, are long, ugly, and lean, have the Hair of their Neck thick, and great Tayls which hang down to the ground; but Nature hath very well repaired their uglineÅ¿s by their Å¿wiftneÅ¿s, and their incomparable and indefatigable Å¿ervice they perform in travelling, being able to carry their Riders whole days journeys without drawing Bit; they feed at all times, and when in winter the Earth is covered with Snow, and the Tartars make their incurÅ¿ions, they live
either upon what is under the Snow, or upon the Branches or Å¿prouts of Trees, Pine tops, Straw, or any thing they can find; the chief of the Tartars have TurkiÅ¿h and Arabian HorÅ¿es, and their Cham very good Race-horÅ¿es.

The travelling Tartars Å¿carce eat any bread coming Å¿eldom into places, where it is to be had, but they make uÅ¿e of Millet, which is very common amongÅ¿t them, with which they make their Drink and Pottage; and eat ordinarily HorÅ¿efleÅ¿h which they boil when they are at leiÅ¿ure, either alone or with their Millet, but when they goe to war and are upon their March, they make it ready, or rather mortify, or juÅ¿t heat it, under their Saddlesâª and eat it afterwards in this condition without any other Å¿auce then the froth upon the FleÅ¿h, made by the Å¿weating of the HorÅ¿e; neither doe they chooÅ¿e the moÅ¿t fat or the moÅ¿t Å¿ound and wholÅ¿ome HorÅ¿es to make their ProviÅ¿ion of, but they take Å¿uch as are Å¿pent with their long marches, or are Å¿ick and
lame, and I have Å¿een at my being in Poland, divers Tartar priÅ¿oners come and take away dead HorÅ¿es out of the Stables to feaÅ¿t one another with, Å¿o that there is no fear in thoÅ¿e Countreys that the carcaÅ¿Å¿es of dead BeaÅ¿ts Å¿hould infect the Air, they will take an order for that, and not fail to carry them away, aÅ¿Å¿oon as they know where they are; the uÅ¿e of Wine being forbidden them by the Law of Mahomet, their drink is ordinarily clear water, and in winter Å¿now, when the Brooks and Rivers are frozen over, and Å¿ometimes the broth made with their HorÅ¿efleÅ¿h, and the Skumme, or elÅ¿e Breha, which is a drink made with boiled Millet, but thoÅ¿e who are better accommodated, and more delicate, drink Mares milk, Mead, and Strong waters, and eat Lamb, Kid, Fowls, and all Å¿ort of Game which they take; they delighting much in Hunting and Fowling; but all abÅ¿tain from Swines-fleÅ¿h, and one may Å¿ay this of them in general, that they are Å¿ober and continent; as for the Cham himÅ¿elf he keeps a
better Table, and fares more deliciouÅ¿ly, is nobly lodged, and lives magnificently, and as becomes one of his Quality.
Their Language is much like the TurkiÅ¿h, both of them having the Å¿ame original, onely the TurkiÅ¿h is more mixed with PerÅ¿ian and Arabick words; their Religion is the Mahumetan.

As to their Morals, there are very few Nations to be found leÅ¿s vitious, for beÅ¿ides their continence, they are extremely Å¿incere, and faithful, they have no Thieves or falÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es amongÅ¿t them, little injuÅ¿tice or violence, and live in Union and great tranquility; as to their haraÅ¿ing the ChriÅ¿tian Countreys, they doe not think they commit any fault or injuÅ¿tice in doing it, Å¿eeing that they are eÅ¿teemed by them as people that are Infidels and abominable.

The marvellous fidelity of the Captive Tartars in Poland is every day to be
obÅ¿erved, who never fail to return at the time appointed, when they are let looÅ¿e upon their word to goe and procure their Liberties by the exchange of PoliÅ¿h priÅ¿oners, which they execute punctually, or return themÅ¿elves not failing a minute; and I have obÅ¿erved that the PoliÅ¿h Gentlemen doe rather truÅ¿t the young Tartars, which are in their Å¿ervice, with the keys of their Money and Jewels, then any other of their HouÅ¿hold.

TheÅ¿e People obey one Prince whom they call their Cham or King; the Polanders name him the Czar or CaeÅ¿ar, he is much reÅ¿pected by his own People and Reigneth deÅ¿potically, as almoÅ¿t all other Mahumetan Princes do; the Cham hath power of nominating his Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿or, who is ordinarily his Son or one of his Brothers, he that is to Å¿ucceed, is called the Galga; the Nobles or moÅ¿t conÅ¿iderable of his Subjects are named Murzas. The Religion of the Praecopian Tartars being Mahumetan, and their Language the TurkiÅ¿h, together with their nearneÅ¿s to ConÅ¿tantinople; the Government alÅ¿o is very like to that of the Turks; the Cham's firÅ¿t MiniÅ¿ter of State is called the Vizier, the Å¿ame as the Grand Signior's; they have alÅ¿o PrieÅ¿ts and Caditi's to doe juÅ¿tice, for the adminiÅ¿tration of which they have

DrunkenneÅ¿s, Murder, Adultery, and Theft are moÅ¿t rigorouÅ¿ly puniÅ¿hed, and though they be much accuÅ¿tomed to rob in War, yet they totally abÅ¿tain from it in their own Countrey, where wearing of any Arms is prohibited them, even in the Cham's Court.

The forces of this Prince are very numerous, for gathering together all the hords, of the Tartars, who doe either obey him or are his Allies, he is able to bring into the field many thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e; they have no Foot but Å¿ome JaniÅ¿aries which they receive from the Turk upon any expedition which they make by his Order or Agreement; there are Å¿ome few GarriÅ¿ons

The wars which the Tartars ordinarily make, are rather an inroad then any thing elÅ¿e.

How Å¿trict peace Å¿oever they have with the ChriÅ¿tians their neighbors, they doe not fail to viÅ¿it them often, either upon their inclination, or upon the Command of the Cham, who always pretends to a Tribute from the MoÅ¿covites and Polanders, which they have paid Å¿ometimes when neceÅ¿Å¿ity hath forced them, and refuÅ¿ed at others, as not being willing to Å¿ubject themÅ¿elves to theÅ¿e acknowledgements towards
Infidels, and thoÅ¿e whom they diÅ¿piÅ¿e.

When the Tartars would make any great inroad either into Poland or MoÅ¿covy; they chooÅ¿e ordinarily the full Moon of January, all the Rivers, Lakes and MarÅ¿hes, being then frozen, and the Earth, eÅ¿pecially in the plain DeÅ¿arts covered with Snow, which is very commodious for their HorÅ¿es which are not Å¿hod; every Tartar carrieth two with him, either for change, or to carry his booty and proviÅ¿ion; neither is his proviÅ¿ion very weighty, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting onely of a little Millet, dried FleÅ¿h powdered after the manner of the Turks, and Å¿ome Garlick, which they hold very proper to digeÅ¿t Å¿o many crude Meats as they eat, and many times they carry nothing, feeding onely upon the fleÅ¿h of their HorÅ¿es which periÅ¿h in their march; they take their way through the Valleys and moÅ¿t obÅ¿cure paÅ¿Å¿ages, that they may not be diÅ¿covered by the CoÅ¿Å¿acks, who always keep Centry and Watch, and are out upon parties to hear news of them, and Å¿o to allarm the Countrey. That which is
moÅ¿t Å¿urpriÅ¿ing is, That in the middle of winter they incamp without fire, for fear of being diÅ¿covered, and eat little but HorÅ¿efleÅ¿h Å¿tewed under their Saddles; when they are arrived at thoÅ¿e places where they intended, whither it be in Æ²krain or elÅ¿ewhere, their Generals let looÅ¿e one third part of their Army, which is divided into divers Troops, and theÅ¿e over-run and pillage all the Countrey five or Å¿ix Leagues about the wings of their Army; their main body in the mean time keeping cloÅ¿e together, to be in a poÅ¿ture to fight their Enemies, if their Å¿hould be occaÅ¿ion; afterwards this party being returned, they let looÅ¿e another in its turn, obÅ¿erving always this Order, That all their Troops which run up and down, may in a few hours return to the body of their Army: after they have pillaged and harraÅ¿ed the Countrey five or Å¿ix days, they return as faÅ¿t as they can, that they may not be Å¿et upon in their retreat, and having regained the open deÅ¿art Plains, where their Body conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of HorÅ¿e,

They make their incurÅ¿ions alÅ¿o in Summer, but not in Å¿uch great numbers, Å¿eldom Å¿o many as ten thouÅ¿and together, and theÅ¿e are the Tartars of Budziak, who at that Å¿eaÅ¿on lead their HorÅ¿es and Cattel into the Plains to feed, and Å¿o getting ground, they of a Å¿uddain run out and take away all they meet; nor is it eaÅ¿ie to Å¿top them but with a thouÅ¿and men, marching always in Tabor.

The Tartars fight not but in great Troops of two, three, or four thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e, and Å¿eldom give battle but when they are much the Å¿tronger, and when their Army is forced and broken up by the enemy, they Å¿catter and diÅ¿perÅ¿e themÅ¿elves into Å¿o many little Troops, that the Polanders and Germans, who march cloÅ¿e and by Å¿quadrons, know not which to Å¿et upon in their retreat; they Å¿hoot their Arrows from behind them, with Å¿uch exactneÅ¿s as to hit

The priÅ¿oners which they take, they make Slaves and Å¿ell them to the Merchants of ConÅ¿tantinople and Caffa, and other places of the EaÅ¿t, who either keep them to wait upon themÅ¿elves, or to look after their Cattle, or till the Ground, entertaining with the Å¿ame face as we have formerly Å¿poken of, as divers PoliÅ¿h and French Officers have related unto me; amongÅ¿t others, Lieutenant-Collonel Nicolai, and Captain CrouÅ¿tade, who moÅ¿t unfortunately fell into their hands; but the Poles are even
with them, for except thoÅ¿e Children whom they chooÅ¿e to wait upon them, and Baptize and inÅ¿truct in the ChriÅ¿tian Religion, or Å¿ome Murza which they Å¿hut up and treat well enough, and hope to exchange for Å¿ome PoliÅ¿h Nobleman, priÅ¿oner in Tartary; the reÅ¿t are kept as Slaves, having always Irons upon their feet, and are made uÅ¿e of as BeaÅ¿ts to carry all manner of burthens, Lime, Brick, and all other materials for building, Wood for their Kitchins and Chambers, and to make clean their HouÅ¿es, and Plough, and other labors, being always followed by one who keeps them to their work, yet theÅ¿e poor people get Å¿ome time to make Whips, which they Å¿ell and buy proviÅ¿ions with the Money, their ordinary allowance being onely Bread and Water, unleÅ¿s when they get a dead HorÅ¿e; when I was at WarÅ¿aw, I had opportunity to take notice of two or three hundred of them, who lived after this manner, either under the King, or Å¿ome great PoliÅ¿h Nobleman.

div.head: THE HISTORY OF THE WAR OF THE COSSACKS AGAINST POLAND.
div.p:
POland hath had often very powerful Enemies to deal with, as the German Empire, the Knights of the Teutonick Order, Å¿ince their eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment in PruÅ¿Å¿ia, often backed by German Forces; the Tartars who have made frequent incurÅ¿ions, and Å¿ometimes traverÅ¿ed the Countrey from one end to the other. Having therefore joyned their forces with thoÅ¿e of the Infidels, they made in leÅ¿s then four years time, four great

Bogdan Kmielniski was the firÅ¿t Å¿park which kindled this fire, and the hinge upon whom this war moved, he was born a Gentleman, Å¿on to the PodÅ¿tarroÅ¿te of a PoliÅ¿h General, being inrolled young in the CoÅ¿Å¿ackian Militia; from a private Å¿oldier he attained by degrees to the charge of a Captain, and was deputed from this Militia to the Diets of Poland, was afterwards made CommiÅ¿Å¿ary-General, and in the end General, having beÅ¿ides this Å¿ome tincture of literature, a thing very rare
in any of thoÅ¿e people; King Æ²ladiÅ¿laus being weary of languiÅ¿hing in a Å¿lothful quietneÅ¿s, while that moÅ¿t part of the other Kings and Princes of ChriÅ¿tendom were in action, in the year 1646. deÅ¿igned a war againÅ¿t the Praecopian Tartars, whom he pretended to drive out of Crimea, and judged Kmielniski, worthy to Command the CoÅ¿Å¿ackian Army, of which he made very great account, eÅ¿pecially in this expedition; but the Kings deÅ¿igne not being Å¿econded by the ChriÅ¿tian Princes, who were employed otherwiÅ¿e, nor by the Venetians themÅ¿elves, upon whoÅ¿e aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance he did very much depend, and on the other Å¿ide the States of Poland being jealous of his raiÅ¿ing forces, he was obliged to disband and pay off his Troops with a good part of his Queens Dowry. Kmielniski was by this means out of Å¿ervice, yet Å¿oon found occaÅ¿ion of imploying himÅ¿elf upon a diÅ¿pute which happened about his EÅ¿tate, between him and Czapliniski, Lieutenant to Konielpolski, Great enÅ¿igne of the Crown, and was the more exaÅ¿perated

Some thought, and with great probability, that King Æ²ladiÅ¿laus, being willing to take in hand again the deÅ¿igne of his expedition againÅ¿t the Tartars, entertained a private correÅ¿pondence with him, and was the cauÅ¿e under-hand that the CoÅ¿Å¿acks revolted, to the end that the States of Poland furniÅ¿hing
him with an Army to Å¿uppreÅ¿s them, when they came to meet, they might joyn their forces, and the greateÅ¿t part being Å¿trangers, and Commanded by thoÅ¿e who are intimate with them, they would little have regarded the Orders of the States, but followed this Prince againÅ¿t the Tartars and againÅ¿t the Turks alÅ¿o, with whom they would neceÅ¿Å¿arily have been ingaged, having attacqued the former; but howÅ¿oever it was, Kmielniski Å¿eeing that the Letters which he Å¿ent into Poland to complain of the injuries done to the CoÅ¿Å¿acks, and to him in particular, although full of Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion and proteÅ¿tations of Obedience, were of no effect; but on the contrary, the Great General Potoski was preparing to come againÅ¿t him; and diÅ¿truÅ¿ting his own Å¿trength, he called for aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance from the Tartars, who paÅ¿Å¿ed the winter in the deÅ¿art Plains, Å¿eeking their opportunity to make their ordinary inroads, and plunder in Æ²krain, conducted by Tohaibeg, one of their Captains, a brave Commander, but often mutinous, and refractory

The great diÅ¿tance of places was favourable to Kmielniski, and kept the PoliÅ¿h Generals Å¿ome time from the knowledge of his private Treaties, but Å¿o Å¿oon as they had certain advice thereof, they reÅ¿olved to march with all diligence towards the Zaporovian IÅ¿lands, and to Å¿tifle this revolt in its Cradle, they diÅ¿patched therefore on that Å¿ide, a part of the PoliÅ¿h Army deÅ¿igned for the Guard of the frontiers, and particularly the body of CoÅ¿Å¿acks entertained in the Å¿ervice of the States under the conduct of Schomberg their CommiÅ¿Å¿ary. Part of the CoÅ¿Å¿ackian Militia which was imbarked upon the BoriÅ¿thenes, being arrived at the Porohi, went immediately over to Kmielniski, violating in favour of their Countrey-men, their Oath of Allegiance to the Polanders, which they had Å¿o lately taken. eaÅ¿ily obliged them to follow the example of the former. among theÅ¿e latter, there were Å¿ome Troops of Dragoons which did excellent Å¿ervice in this war againÅ¿t the PoliÅ¿h Nobility, who to Å¿ave the charges of a German Guard, which the Gentlemen of that Countrey uÅ¿ed to have about their perÅ¿ons, had Armed and Habited many of thoÅ¿e Countrey-men after the faÅ¿hion of the German Dragoons, renewing thus their courage by the change of their condition, and bringing them out of the baÅ¿eneÅ¿s of Å¿lavery. Kmielniski fortified with theÅ¿e revolting CoÅ¿Å¿acks, found no great difficulty to overcome the reÅ¿t of the PoliÅ¿h Troops, who were not in all above fifteen hundred men; the Poles defended themÅ¿elves Å¿ome days in the middle of their Tabor, A certain intrenchment made with their Chariots but having loÅ¿t their Canon, and not being able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t Å¿o great a number which encompaÅ¿Å¿ed them on all Å¿ides, they were all either Å¿lain or made Å¿laves by the Tartars; Sapitza was one of theÅ¿e, Schomberg was mortally wounded, and Potoski not being able to be carried away,

Kmielniski carefully managing this advantage, had the Glory which ordinarily accompanies the firÅ¿t victory, made head againÅ¿t the reÅ¿t of the PoliÅ¿h Army, which conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of about five thouÅ¿and men, and whoÅ¿e Commanders having long expected the news of their firÅ¿t Troops ordered towards the BoriÅ¿thenes, and now being certainly informed of their defeat, as that alÅ¿o the CoÅ¿Å¿acks had deÅ¿erted them, and that the Tartars were joyned with the Rebels, thought it neceÅ¿Å¿ary to retreat, for the preÅ¿ervation of the forces of the Kingdom, but it was now too late, for the Bacmates So they call the Tartarian HorÅ¿es. overtaking them, began to skirmiÅ¿h with them, and Å¿ome Tartars being taken priÅ¿oners, did confeÅ¿s upon the Rack, that their Army conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of forty thouÅ¿and men, beÅ¿ides Å¿even thouÅ¿and CoÅ¿Å¿acks, and the Countreymen of the adjacent Colonies who came in hourly to them. The PoliÅ¿h Council of War deliberating therefore what was to be done, found no expedient better then that of continuing their retreat in the middle

This misfortune which happened about KorÅ¿un, became more Å¿enÅ¿ible to Poland by reaÅ¿on of the death of King Æ²ladiÅ¿laus the IV who died at this time at Mereche in Lithuania in the two and fiftieth year of his age, no man doubting but this Prince by his valour joyned with all thoÅ¿e other great perfections which he was endowed with, and which made him venerable and beloved by his own, as well as eÅ¿teemed

The Kings death was not preÅ¿ently known to Kmielniski, who, if he had been informed of it, would not have failed to have Å¿hown more fierceneÅ¿s then he did after the defeat of the PoliÅ¿h Army; upon which he wrote a very Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ive Letter to the King, in which he laid all that was paÅ¿Å¿ed upon the inÅ¿olence of the Governors, and upon the Rapines and inÅ¿upportable Exactions of the Jews, who for Farmers of the Kings Land, and of many Gentlemens EÅ¿tates, he asked pardon for what he was conÅ¿trained to doe in his own defencc, promiÅ¿ed to Å¿end back the Tartars, and to live in obedience to his MajeÅ¿ty, if he would be pleaÅ¿ed to maintain him and his CoÅ¿Å¿acks in their liberty and priviledges granted them by the former Kings his predeceÅ¿Å¿ors, but a while after he underÅ¿tood the King was dead, by a Letter Å¿ent him

In execution of which Articles, the General coming before the King fell upon his knees, and with tears in his eyes, made a long diÅ¿courÅ¿e, expreÅ¿Å¿ing himÅ¿elf how he had much rather appeared in his preÅ¿ence, to receive his approbation for Å¿ome conÅ¿iderable Å¿ervice done to his MajeÅ¿ty, and the State, then thus Å¿tained with Å¿o much Blood. But Å¿ince that the deÅ¿tinies had diÅ¿poÅ¿ed it otherwiÅ¿e, he came to implore his clemency; and in all humility, the forgiveneÅ¿s of his faults, promiÅ¿ing to repair them by his future conduct. The King anÅ¿wered him by the Vice-chancellor of Lithuania, That the Repentance of his Subjects was more acceptable to him, then their puniÅ¿hment; and that he did heartily forgive what was paÅ¿Å¿ed, if he would efface the crime which he had committed by his future Zeal and Fidelity to his Countrey.

After this action, Kmielniski and the Cham cauÅ¿ed their Forces to retire,
and the King extreamly happy in eÅ¿caping Å¿o great a danger, at Å¿o eaÅ¿ie a rate, went with the PoliÅ¿h Army to Gliniani, and afterwards to Leopold.
ThoÅ¿e Forces intrenched at Zbaras, reduced to thoÅ¿e extremities which you have already heard of, maintained themÅ¿elves all along, rather by rage and deÅ¿pair, then any hope of help.

The Inhabitants of that Town, not being able to Å¿uffer the utmoÅ¿t extremity of Famine, were ready either to burn the Town, or deliver it up to the enemy; but the vigilance of the Polanders having hindred the execution of this tragick deÅ¿ign, they much Å¿ollicited to be let out, which was onely granted to their Wives and Children; neither were they able to keep their retreat undiÅ¿covered, but fell firÅ¿t into the hands of the PoliÅ¿h Soldiers, who abuÅ¿ed them as they pleaÅ¿ed, and afterwards of the Tartars, who led this unfortunate Troop into captivity together with Å¿ome Servants of the Army who had followed them.

The One and twentieth of August, the CoÅ¿Å¿acks Å¿ent the firÅ¿t news to the beÅ¿ieged of the Peace concluded at Zborow, which was believed by Å¿ome, but called in queÅ¿tion by moÅ¿t, who feared they might not be comprehended in that Treaty; they were confirmed in this opinion by a Trumpet, who had the boldneÅ¿s to proclaim the Å¿ame upon his own accord; and it had coÅ¿t him his life, if one of the Generals had not interceded for him: Afterwards there came a Letter from Kmielniski, in which, he aÅ¿Å¿ured the beÅ¿ieged of their Deliverance upon the payment of a certain Å¿um to the Tartars; but the Generals would not accept of this condition, and openly declared, that Å¿ince Kmielniski was obliged to draw off his Forces, he ought to do it; and for the Tartars, if they would remain where they were, they might do Å¿o if they pleaÅ¿ed. In the end, a more faithful and joyful MeÅ¿Å¿age was brought them, with a Letter by Colonel Minor from the King, to aÅ¿Å¿ure them of their Liberties
without any conditions, together with the diÅ¿poÅ¿al of the Palatinate of Seudomire, vacant by the Death of the Duke of ZaÅ¿law, with which his MajeÅ¿ty would gratifie the Å¿ervices of General Firley. The Prince WiÅ¿nowitskie was preÅ¿ented with the StarroÅ¿ty of PremiÅ¿li, the Duke of OÅ¿trog with that of NeÅ¿Å¿ewitz, Landskoronski with that of Stobnitz, and the Palatinate of Braclaw.

All theÅ¿e recompenÅ¿es, although very conÅ¿iderable, yet were they inferior to that valor and heroical ConÅ¿tancy; of which, all theÅ¿e great perÅ¿ons had given Å¿uch fair proofs, during thoÅ¿e two Moneths which they were beÅ¿ieged, and continually aÅ¿Å¿aulted in Zbaras.

Neither was Providence leÅ¿s favorable to the Polanders in Lithuania, then in RuÅ¿Å¿ia, where two of their Armies were, as it were, led by the hand out of a danger; wherein according to all humane appearance, they muÅ¿t have periÅ¿hed.

The Rebellion of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks and PeaÅ¿ants Å¿pred it Å¿elf in the beginning of the War, with Å¿o much more eaÅ¿e into Lithuania, by reaÅ¿on that the Inhabitants of that Countrey, are more conformable in their Manners and Religion with the RuÅ¿Å¿es.

The CoÅ¿Å¿acks, entring at two places, had made their inrodes into PoleÅ¿ia, a Countrey full of Woods and Bogs, and which makes a part of the Palatinates of Kiovia and Volhinia, and by treachery had Å¿eiÅ¿ed upon the Inhabitants of Starodub and Homel, people who had favored their irruption. Colonel Patz and Volowitz, and afterward Prince Janus Radzevil, General of Samogitia, and Field-MarÅ¿hal of Lithuania, oppoÅ¿ed their deÅ¿igns as well as they could, with the Nobility of OrÅ¿a; the GarriÅ¿on of Bichova, and Å¿ome other Forces gathered together; but the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the State came very Å¿lowly, and Prince Radzevil being Å¿ent for to the Diet. The Rebels made uÅ¿e of this occaÅ¿ion
of his abÅ¿ence, and Å¿et upon Sluczk, a Town belonging to Prince BogiÅ¿laus Radzevil, Great MaÅ¿ter of the HorÅ¿e of Lithuania. SoÅ¿nowski, who was Governor of it, defended it bravely againÅ¿t them; and Horsch, Governor of OrÅ¿a, defeated Fifteen hundred Men at Czeresko, and Mirski, Major General of the Lithuanian Army, retook from them Prinsko, a populous Town, and the Seat of a Greek BiÅ¿hop, which they had made themÅ¿elves MaÅ¿ters of, by the treachery of the Inhabitants. Hladki one of the Principal Commanders of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks, who was within to defend it, was Å¿lain; and becauÅ¿e this place was one of their principal retreats, it was Å¿acked and burnt to aÅ¿hes to Å¿erve for an example.

Prince Radzevil returning from the Election of the King of Poland, although the Å¿eaÅ¿on of the year was very unfit for War; after that he had reduced onely by the fame of his approach, the Towns of Turow and Grodek, went and laid down before Mozyr, which
being defended for Å¿ome days very obÅ¿tinately, was taken by Å¿torm by Ganskowski, Lieutenant Colonel in Radzevil's Regiment, and Michnenko, one of the chief of the Rebels, being taken therein, the Prince commanded he Å¿hould be beheaded by the Common Hangman, and his Head Å¿et upon the top of the CaÅ¿tle.

From thence he marched with his Forces towards the River Berezina, where he attacked Bobroisko; the Inhabitants were received into grace, upon condition, That they would deliver up their Arms; and thoÅ¿e among them, who had been the Authors of this InÅ¿urrection, or who had made a League with the CoÅ¿Å¿acks; which coming to the knowledge of thoÅ¿e who were to be delivered up, they retreated into a Tower, and Å¿et it on fire, preferring this voluntary death, before that with which the Conqueror threatned them. Produbitz who commanded them, received with the reÅ¿t the puniÅ¿hment of his Rebellion.

The Winter and the Truce put a Å¿top to the War in Lithuania, as well as in Poland for Å¿ome Moneths; but in the Spring, Kmielniski entring into the Kingdom again, Å¿ent into this Province Helia Holota to renew the War with Ten thouÅ¿and Men, to whom many Rebellious PeaÅ¿ants were to joyn themÅ¿elves. This General thought to Å¿urpriÅ¿e part of the Lithuanian Army in their Winter-quarters at Zahal, upon the River of Pripecz; but Radzevil's Forces gathering together in haÅ¿te put them to flight, and drove them into a MarÅ¿h, where he and his Army periÅ¿hed. Stephen Podobaylo was Å¿ubÅ¿tituted in his place by Kmielniski, who gave him order to intrench himÅ¿elf between the Boristhenes, and the River of Zula, which he did, and Å¿et fire on Loiowogrod, leaÅ¿t it Å¿hould Å¿erve for a place of retreat to the Lithuanians: Yet Gozieuski Å¿etting forward with Å¿ome Troops to oppoÅ¿e his deÅ¿igns, having Å¿ent Å¿ome Foot down the Boristhenes, Å¿eiÅ¿ed on a place capable of incommodating him
very much. After this Kmielniski Å¿ent again into Lithuania Thirty thouÅ¿and Men, under the Command of Crziezeuski, a PoliÅ¿h Gentleman.

This Commander had procured Kmielniski liberty, when he had been taken by the Poles, and had received the Å¿ame favor from him again; the laÅ¿t year, after the defeat of the PoliÅ¿h Army at CarÅ¿un, and the favorable entertainment he received, together with the fortunate poÅ¿ture of Kmielniski's affairs, engaged him in his Å¿ervice. Being therefore entred into Lithuania, after he had paÅ¿Å¿ed the Pripecz, he made as if he would beÅ¿iege Rzeczicza, a Town very advantagiouÅ¿ly Å¿eated; but marched directly againÅ¿t Prince Radzevil's Army, imaging upon the advice that was given him, That this Prince had Å¿ent out Å¿ome Regiments, he might eaÅ¿ily force the reÅ¿t, and came very near before they had news of his march. But Chodorkowitz went out with Å¿ome HorÅ¿e, at the firÅ¿t noiÅ¿e of them, and being backed with Four hundred Foot,
commanded by Podlek and Juskiewitz, he oppoÅ¿ed himÅ¿elf againÅ¿t the firÅ¿t OnÅ¿et of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks; and receiving divers charges from them, the reÅ¿t of the Troops had leiÅ¿ure to put themÅ¿elves in Bataglia: And at length Gonzieuski and Niewarowitz, with the HuÅ¿Å¿ars forced the Left-wing of the Enemy into a Wood, where at firÅ¿t they made a great firing, and overthrew divers who advanced too far; but at laÅ¿t, being conÅ¿trained to retreat farther in, they were not in condition to fight any longer.

In the mean time, Å¿ome Squadrons, which the heat of the engagement had drawn out too far, were incompaÅ¿Å¿ed in by the CoÅ¿Å¿acks, and ready to be cut in pieces, if that Komorouski, whom Prince Radzevil had Å¿ent before with a thouÅ¿and Men to diÅ¿cover and take priÅ¿oners, had not happily come in and diÅ¿ingaged them. He that commanded the Right-wing of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks, Å¿eeing this Recruit, and apprehending that it might be followed by a greater, and
that Å¿ome AmbuÅ¿h was preparing for him retreated alÅ¿o into the Wood, and wherein he thought himÅ¿elf not Å¿ecure enough, till he had intrenched himÅ¿elf. While theÅ¿e things were doing, the CoÅ¿Å¿ackian General Podobailo, who was coming to the relief of Crziezeuski with Twelve thouÅ¿and Men, paÅ¿Å¿ed the Boristhenes in Boats: And it is certain, if he had arrived a little Å¿ooner, and before the other Troops had been broken, the Lithuanian Army had been in extream danger; but the Forces of Podobailo were Å¿carce half paÅ¿Å¿ed over, and had begun to intrench themÅ¿elves, when Prince Radzevil marched directly towards them, and after a fierce charge, put them to the rout, and drove them into the River. So that beÅ¿ides Three or four hundred which Å¿aved themÅ¿elves by Å¿wimming, Four thouÅ¿and five hundred of them were either killed or drowned. Colonel TiÅ¿enhauÅ¿en, Nold, and Fechtman, with their Germans, fell upon the reÅ¿t of Podobailo's Forces, who with their Tabor went to joyn themÅ¿elves to Crziezeuski.

This General coming out of the Wood, wherein he had retreated to receive them, was preÅ¿ently wedged in again by the HuÅ¿Å¿ars, and forced to intrench in haÅ¿te with Arms of Trees broken off, or any thing that came to hand; even with dead bodies. And having underÅ¿tood that night by his Spies, that Prince Radzevil prepared for a new attack the next morning, he retreated in all haÅ¿te; leaving the heavieÅ¿t of his Baggage behind him, and he himÅ¿elf being wounded in many places, was left by the way, and fell into the hands of the Lithuanians, and died Å¿ome time after in their Camp. NotwithÅ¿tanding this Å¿hock, the War was kindled Å¿till more fiercely, and many thouÅ¿and CoÅ¿Å¿acks had paÅ¿Å¿ed the Pripecz at Babica, to make a new irruption into Lithuania, and to reinforce their party when the peace at Zborow was concluded. In execution of which Treaty, the CoÅ¿Å¿acks were called back out of this Country as well as out of Poland.

div.head: THE SECOND WAR OF THE COSSACKS AGAINST POLAND.
div.p:
THe King of Poland returning to WarÅ¿aw, in the midÅ¿t of the Acclamations of his People, who could not Å¿ufficiently expreÅ¿s their joy and acknowledgments to him, for what he had done for the preÅ¿ervation of the Kingdom; applied himÅ¿elf with all diligence in the Diet, which he held towards the end of the year, to the eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment of the Peace lately concluded with the Tartars and CoÅ¿Å¿acks.
The reÅ¿ult of this Diet, which ended the Twelfth of January, One thouÅ¿and Å¿ix hundred and fifty, was, That all the PoliÅ¿h Soldiers Å¿hould be immediately Å¿atisfied: That the Army which had been Å¿hut up at Zbaras, in conÅ¿ideration of their great Å¿ervices, Å¿hould receive three payments extraordinary, there Å¿hould be Twelve thouÅ¿and Men in continual pay for the Guard of the Frontiers: That the Articles concluded on, between the King, and the CoÅ¿Å¿acks and Tartars at Zborow, Å¿hould be confirmed: That three of the CoÅ¿Å¿ackian Gentlemen Å¿hould be admitted to Publick Offices: And that for the Å¿upply of theÅ¿e great expences, there Å¿hould be a new ImpoÅ¿t laid upon all Poland and Lithuania; and CuÅ¿toms upon MerchandiÅ¿es granted to his MajeÅ¿ty, for his Signal Exploits in the laÅ¿t Campagnia.

It was alÅ¿o thought fit to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h a Senator at Kiovia, to be vigilant, near at hand, over the Actions of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks, and to decide the differences which might ariÅ¿e in performance of the Treaty.
Adam KiÅ¿iel, appointed a while after, to be Governor of that Town, was thought to be a perÅ¿on moÅ¿t able to acquit himÅ¿elf worthily in that charge, and to regiÅ¿ter the Forty thouÅ¿and Men, of which the CoÅ¿Å¿ackian Army was to conÅ¿iÅ¿t, according to the laÅ¿t Treaty, and to give them their neceÅ¿Å¿ary inÅ¿tructions.

Kmielniski obÅ¿erved this Peace almoÅ¿t a year, and teÅ¿tified in all appearance his good intentions; but apprehending leaÅ¿t the Polanders whom he had forced, in the unhappy conjuncture of their affairs, to grant him extraordinary conditions, Å¿hould now repent of it, and Å¿earch out ways to elude the performance of them; he thought that he could not do better then by powerful Alliances, to Å¿ecure to himÅ¿elf theÅ¿e advantages which had been conceded.

And to this intent, he applied himÅ¿elf to the Grand Signior, and the Great Duke of MuÅ¿covy; but eÅ¿pecially to the firÅ¿t, by whoÅ¿e favor he hoped
to render himÅ¿elf conÅ¿iderable to all the World. He pretended alÅ¿o to deÅ¿ire the FriendÅ¿hip of the HoÅ¿podar or Prince of Moldavia; but it was onely to amuÅ¿e him, that he might the better Å¿urpriÅ¿e him, and force his Countrey: For in the mean time he made an ill impreÅ¿Å¿ion of him upon the mindes of the Grand Signiors Officers, to whom he repreÅ¿ented him as a Å¿ecret enemy to the Turks, and an intimate Friend of the Polanders; and that by his means, the Poles had hitherto received continual intelligence of theirs, and the Tartars deÅ¿igns. They aÅ¿Å¿ured therefore Kmielniski of the Protection of the Grand Signior, and that he Å¿hould be inveÅ¿ted with Black RuÅ¿Å¿ia, to hold it in Fee of the Ottoman Empire; they received the acknowledgments of his dependance on them, and his promiÅ¿es of fidelity in their Å¿ervice, and permitted him to execute his deÅ¿igns againÅ¿t the Prince of Moldavia, which he did with great diÅ¿Å¿imulation, and made uÅ¿e of the Tartars in it; to whom he joyned onely Four thouÅ¿and CoÅ¿Å¿acks, and the
better to keep Å¿ecret his intentions. The Cham Å¿ent to him to thank him for his aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance againÅ¿t the CircaÅ¿Å¿ians, and deÅ¿ired further, that he would lend him his Forces to go againÅ¿t MoÅ¿covy, to revenge the injuries which he had received from the Great Duke: So that while the Neighboring Princes perÅ¿waded themÅ¿elves, that the Tartars were going to War in MoÅ¿covia, the HoÅ¿podar of Moldavia, who was one of this number, and lived in the ordinary careleÅ¿s Å¿ecurity of a high Peace, found himÅ¿elf encompaÅ¿Å¿ed in with a numerous Army of Tartars, and the Four thouÅ¿and Auxiliary CoÅ¿Å¿acks. All that could be done upon Å¿o Å¿udden and unexpected an accident, was to run into the Woods near JaÅ¿z, his principal City. In the thickeÅ¿t of which, the HoÅ¿podar, with his family, and as many as he could get together in haÅ¿te, intrenched themÅ¿elves with Trees cut down; and afterwards drew himÅ¿elf out of this danger, upon the payment of Twenty thouÅ¿and Ducats to the Tartars, and the promiÅ¿e of his Daughter in marriage to Timotheus
Kmielniski his Son: Upon which condition Kmielniski did recede from many hard terms which he had put upon the HoÅ¿podar.

In the mean time, the Peace with the Poles was every day violated by the CoÅ¿Å¿acks; their numerous Army was extended much beyond their quarters. The PeaÅ¿ants who were not inrolled, Å¿uÅ¿tained by them, would not receive thoÅ¿e Gentlemen, their Landlords, who were to enter upon poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of their EÅ¿tates again, but treated them ill, and maÅ¿Å¿acred divers. This deportment of theirs, and the expedition againÅ¿t Moldavia, obliged Potoski, the GeneraliÅ¿Å¿imo, who was newly returned out of his priÅ¿on in Tartary, to march with the PoliÅ¿h Army, and incamp near CamieneÅ¿che.

Kmielniski was much Å¿urpriÅ¿ed at the firÅ¿t news of this march; and there being with him at that time divers who were deputed from the Nobility, to complain of the Rebellion, in the
which the PeaÅ¿ants perÅ¿iÅ¿ted, and their refuÅ¿al to acknowledge them; he commanded, that all thoÅ¿e who were Å¿ent to him, Å¿hould be drowned the night following. But theÅ¿e Orders being given when he was in drink, filled with Wine and Strong-waters, after he had digeÅ¿ted his debauch, and been informed by his Wife of what he had done, he preÅ¿ently revoked his Å¿entence juÅ¿t when they who had the charge of it, were ready to execute it. Afterwards he Å¿ent Craucenski, one of his Officers, to the General Potoski, to give him to underÅ¿tand, That he could not but be aÅ¿toniÅ¿hed at the approach of the PoliÅ¿h Forces, in Å¿uch a time, when they had Peace with all the World, and a powerful Army of CoÅ¿Å¿acks at their diÅ¿poÅ¿al for the Å¿ecurity of the Frontiers.

The General in anÅ¿wer reproached him for their daily breach of Peace, and the ill Treatment which the Nobility received from their Subjects; and for the War which Kmielniski had undertaken without their knowledge
againÅ¿t the Prince of Moldavia; and that although he were Great General to the States of Poland, yet he ought to have advertiÅ¿ed them of it; he added, that he could not leave that Å¿tation wherein he was by the Kings Order, without expreÅ¿s command from his MajeÅ¿ty.

This AnÅ¿wer was no way pleaÅ¿ing to the Envoy from Kmielniski, who declared how much his MaÅ¿ter would be ill Å¿atisfied with it, and mingled threatnings of War with his diÅ¿courÅ¿e; but proceeded not to breach of Peace, either by reaÅ¿on of the nearneÅ¿s of the PoliÅ¿h Army, and the Great General, whoÅ¿e admired deÅ¿ert or redoubted courage, might turn him from it; or becauÅ¿e, that the deÅ¿igns he laid of raiÅ¿ing a Principality for himÅ¿elf, were not yet mature enough to diÅ¿cloÅ¿e this ambitious project; or, that he was willing to Å¿et down contented with his expedition into Moldavia, and with having made a new Alliance, although by force of Arms.

In the mean time the Nobility in Æ² kraine were as ill treated, as if it had been in time of War; Å¿o that many were obliged every day to retire. ThoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons who had great eÅ¿tates, and the Duke of WiÅ¿nowitz, in particular, received Å¿carce any Rents; the continual complaints of which to the King, induced him to write to Kmielniski, and to reproach him for the War which he had undertaken, contrary to his order, againÅ¿t the HoÅ¿podar of Moldavia, and for the injuries which the Nobility received, injoyning him to draw back the Zapoovian Army into their quarters, and to chaÅ¿tiÅ¿e the PeaÅ¿ants who had taken Arms againÅ¿t their Lords.

This Letter was received with great reÅ¿pect in appearance, but he proceeded with much Å¿lowneÅ¿s, to execute what the King required of him; and on the contrary, was very induÅ¿trious at the Å¿ame time, to make a Å¿trict League with the Turk, and Great Duke of MoÅ¿covy, whoÅ¿e friendÅ¿hip he deÅ¿ired with the
more importunity, by reaÅ¿on that he promiÅ¿ed himÅ¿elf more Å¿ecurity and advantage in his Alliance, then in the others, becauÅ¿e of the Conformity of the Religion of the MuÅ¿covites with the CoÅ¿Å¿acks. The Great Duke approved not of this Rebellion, yet deÅ¿ired to make his advantage by it.

The great Å¿ucceÅ¿s which Kmielniski had had againÅ¿t the Poles, made him eÅ¿teem them as a defeated and depreÅ¿Å¿ed people, and to begin a cauÅ¿leÅ¿s quarrel with them, in hopes to obtain from them, during the bad condition of their affairs, a revocation of the Treaty, which he had been forced to make with King Æ²ladiÅ¿laus before Smolenko, when his whole Army was diÅ¿armed and taken which beÅ¿ieged that FortreÅ¿s: He demanded alÅ¿o, in Å¿atisfaction for the affronts done him by Å¿ome of the PoliÅ¿h Nobility, and among others, by Prince Witnowitski and KonieÅ¿polski; who had not onely neglected to give him all his titles, but had alÅ¿o written in terms injurious to the reputation of the MoÅ¿covite
Nation; that the States of Poland Å¿hould give up to him the City of Smolensko with its dependances, and Å¿hould pay him the Å¿um of an Hundred and fourÅ¿core thouÅ¿and Ducats. VVhereupon his MajeÅ¿ty of Poland having Å¿ent a Gentleman, named Barlinski, to the Great Duke, to be more clearly informed concerning the inÅ¿olent demands of his AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador; upon whom, in the mean time, he had Å¿et a Guard. This Envoy brought back an AnÅ¿wer, which teÅ¿tified rather the inclination the MoÅ¿covite had to obÅ¿erve the former Treaties with Poland, then to come to a breach; and in effect, although the Great Duke would with much joy have Å¿een the increaÅ¿e of the Greek Religion, yet he could not look with a good eye upon the growing greatneÅ¿s of Kmielniski, nor be without Å¿ome apprehenÅ¿ion, that the Rebellion of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks and PeaÅ¿ants, might alÅ¿o Å¿pred it Å¿elf into his own Countrey, whither already Å¿ome Å¿parks had flown of that fire which had burned Poland. So that the MoÅ¿covite AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador was forced to declare
in the preÅ¿ence of the King, and the Senators, That he, of his own head, had prepared thoÅ¿e PropoÅ¿itions which he had delivered, and the Peace was confirmed between the Poles, and the Great Duke.

The continual correÅ¿pondence which Kmielniski held with the Turks, of which, the King of Poland was advertiÅ¿ed by the Neighboring Princes, and his inÅ¿olent carriage towards the State, obliged his MajeÅ¿ty to call a General Diet of the Kingdom, in the end of the year One thouÅ¿and Å¿ix hundred and fifty; in which, this Prince repreÅ¿ented the inÅ¿upportable behavior of the General of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks; the contempt he had both of the King and State; the injuries which many of the Nobility had received; the loÅ¿s of their EÅ¿tates, and their not being able to be reÅ¿tored againÅ¿t Kmielniski his great forces, which he Å¿trove to increaÅ¿e by the addition of Tartars and Turks; Å¿o that he was in a condition to gather together on the Å¿uddain, an Army of more then FourÅ¿core
thouÅ¿and Men, every CoÅ¿Å¿ack inrolled, of which, the number by the laÅ¿t Treaty, amounted to Forty thouÅ¿and; had a Å¿ervant on Horsback, and another on Foot, beÅ¿ides a Laborer to Till the Grounds; that their deÅ¿ign was to Å¿hake off utterly all obedience, and to Å¿et up a new Government under the Protection of the Grand Signior: So that they would be capable of performing any thing, if that they did not Å¿oon put a Å¿top to the courÅ¿e of their pernicious deÅ¿igns.

There were Å¿ome in the AÅ¿Å¿embly, who calling to minde the evils, cauÅ¿ed by the laÅ¿t VVar, were of opinion, That Peace at any rate was to be preferred before it; and alledged, that the Forces of the Kingdom were now notably decreaÅ¿ed, whereas thoÅ¿e of the CoÅ¿Å¿acks were very powerful, both of themÅ¿elves, and by the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Ottoman family which protected them; Å¿o that it would be much better to keep cloÅ¿e to the Treaty of Zborow: But the greater number making reflections upon what was paÅ¿Å¿ed, and what was to be
